page.title: 06LOCAL HISTORY OF SANDHURST
page.content: EVIDENCE OF THE PAST Sandhurst actually appears in the original Domesday Book as SANHER and there are many 12th and 13th century references too. The name probably means Â£a sandy hurst or hill', referring to its site. Fish pools were built by monks near what is now Bengrove Farm. There is evidence of Roman occupation near Sandhurst Hill and local legend has it that they Â£fished for mussels'in the Severn near the present Mussel End. Queen Elizabeth I granted the rights for a ferry across the river between Ashleworth Quay and the road to Brawn Farm, this no longer operates. Moat Farm still shows evidence of a medieval moat around the site. In Maisemore parish west of the river, the land was owned by the Church Com- missioners until the 1940s when Chargy and Overton Farms were sold to tenants.
